results.title: Birth reborn
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Forty Minutes”.
Looks at the work in France of Dr Michael Odent who firmly opposes standard medical thinking on childbirth practices. He advocates that women should be able to give birth in the position in which they feel most comfortable rather than being forced into the “stranded beetle” (legs in stirrups) position commonly used in hospitals. Shows a series of births in which Dr Odent helps women to give birth naturally and with a minimum amount of pain. Also depicts the work of Dr Odent in his pre-birth classes where he encourages women to give birth in different positions: standing or squatting. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.

results.title: Birth of the soil
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and George E. Brewer Jnr
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Living Earth”.
This film shows how nature produces life-giving topsoil from the basic raw materials of rock, air, and sunlight, by the processes of plant growth and decay and photosynthesis.

results.title: Birth of the red kangaroo
results.brief_description: Shows mating, the female kangaroo’s preparation for the birth of her young and birth itself. Explains the significance of the oestrous cycle and gestation period, egg fertilization, and the development of the embryo in the uterus. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Birth of the bomb [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Peter Batty Productions and Peter Batty
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visions of War”.
This is the background story of the making of the first atomic bomb. The period covered is from 1938 to the dropping of the bomb on Hiroshima in 1945. German efforts to create an atomic bomb are described. The intensive research into the development of the bomb in the United States is dealt with extensively. Includes archival film and interviews with some of those involved. (Black and white version)

results.title: Birth of language (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: High Road Productions Inc and Paul Jay
results.brief_description: The Birth of Language explores the origin of human language. It examines the differences between human language and animal communication, the relationship of language and thought. The film traces the evolution of humans and their separation from animals.
results.creator_credit_for_label: High Road Productions Inc and Paul Jay

results.title: Birth of Indigenous broadcasting
results.brief_description: From the 1970s, Aboriginal Elders in Central Australia were concerned that satellite TV could potentially bring non-Indigenous stories to remote Aboriginal communities. In response, several Aboriginal media organisations broadcast local content via videotape and pirate TV, leading to the eventual establishment of Indigenous broadcasters.

constellations_primary.name: Broadcasting marginal voices
constellations_primary.description: The creation of Indigenous broadcasting in Central Australia from the late 1970s meant an array of diverse Black stories could be shared. Today, important stories told by those who physically and metaphorically live on the margins can be broadcast widely.

results.description: From the 1970s, Aboriginal Elders in Central Australia were concerned satellite TV potentially bringing non-Indigenous stories and storytelling to remote Aboriginal communities. In response, several Aboriginal media organisations, like Ernabella Video Television (EVTV) and the Warlpiri Media Association (WMA), broadcast local content via videotape and pirate TV in the early 1980s. Filmed in Aboriginal languages, these videos included community events, ceremonies, lore and culture. In 1998, the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA) launched the world’s first Indigenous owned and operated TV network, Imparja Television. Along with the establishment of Indigenous Community Television (ICTV) in 2001, these early initiatives paved the way for other broadcasters, including Goolarri Media Enterprises and National Indigenous Television (NITV).
description_for_label: From the 1970s, Aboriginal Elders in Central Australia were concerned satellite TV potentially bringing non-Indigenous stories and storytelling to remote Aboriginal communities. In response, several Aboriginal media organisations, like Ernabella Video Television (EVTV) and the Warlpiri Media Association (WMA), broadcast local content via videotape and pirate TV in the early 1980s. Filmed in Aboriginal languages, these videos included community events, ceremonies, lore and culture. In 1998, the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association (CAAMA) launched the world’s first Indigenous owned and operated TV network, Imparja Television. Along with the establishment of Indigenous Community Television (ICTV) in 2001, these early initiatives paved the way for other broadcasters, including Goolarri Media Enterprises and National Indigenous Television (NITV).

results.title: Birth of an oilfield
results.brief_description: Shows how an oil well is drilled and crude oil is brought up from the ground and started on its way to the refinery. While live action is used to show glimpses of a drilling crew at work animation reveals what is taking place below the surface of the ground. No credits available.

results.title: Birth of an island
results.brief_description: Shows the formation of the new volcanic island of Surtsey near Iceland, beginning as a submarine eruption and building up to a substantiasl lava shield of several square miles. Covers the changes in activity of the volcano and investigation by landing parties. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.
